description.text: This thing was made with Tinkercad. Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/3TXnOSkzFbl
Red incense holder, composed of ABS PLASTIC.

Hello again! Eddie is back and he's excited to show off his improvements. This is EddiePlus and he has a much cleaner look, new accessories, and vastly improved performance. All the great features of the original Eddie still exist:
  • Rechargeable
  • WiFi Enabled
  • Remote Control
  • FPV Capable
  • Open Source
  • 1 hour drive time with USB camera active
    • New features with EddiePlus:
  • Wheel/Motor encoders
  • Faster Motors -- More speed!
  • Bigger Wheels
  • Dual PID control on each wheel
  • Dynamic balance
  • No exposed screws
  • Interchangeable head designs
  • Backpack to keep electronics safe
  • Build Guide to assist in assembly
  • iOS application Special thanks to David Glinski for this contribution.
  • Python control Special thanks to William Radigan for this contribution.
  • Windows application Special thanks to Eric Jastram for this contribution.
    • Upcoming features:
  • Bluetooth control
    • Eddie's source code is available on github:
    https://github.com/r3n33/EddieBalance Demo videos:

  • EddiePlus can adapt to varying carry loads
    http://youtu.be/LNMD3ySDc_8

  • EddiePlus doesn't mind slopes
    http://youtu.be/1JDhUngas1Q

  • EddiePlus is learning to dance
    http://youtu.be/weLLFOMiZC8

  • EddiePlus likes to be remote controlled
    http://youtu.be/2_HegEclIyQ
    • That is about all I have at the moment for Eddie. I'll be posting new videos, photos, and 3D models as they come and Eddie can be followed on twitter @EddieBalance. I'm hoping others will build to expand and improve upon my design. This was started as a fun project because I wanted to make a self balancing robot and I think he came out so great that I wanted to share him with everyone. If you need help building your Eddie please send me a message here or @EddieBalance Thanks for looking!

Please see the EddiePlus Builder's Guide I've started on google drive: https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B0pRXCySIopjcWRlSXN6NmRXdG8/view?usp=sharing I've also started a Software Setup Guide to get you going once you've built your Eddie: https://docs.google.com/document/d/1PgfG7jG9S5WKtWNUWPfE_pCwGTvZIW7KWqiPiXg1M0w/view

comments.text: That's great you'll be building one as well! Unfortunately I do not think I have much information about installing a webcam head but here is what I can tell you. Not all cameras will work so it would be best to test before cutting wires or taking anything apart. A small and light camera is nice but if it is too heavy you can adjust the balance PIDs on the robot to stop it from falling over. Once the camera is known to work I like to shorten the cable and change the USB connector from A to micro for use on the OTG port.

comments.text: Thank you. There are no sensors in the arms. Eddie senses his current angle with an IMU and how much his wheels move with encoders. title: Majora's Mask Necklace
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A necklace, shaped like the infamous mask. I looked all through the Google Sketchup Warehouse to try to find a good file I could modify, but most of them were folded 2d files, and while trying to modify the one's that weren't, I realized I'm not good enough at anything but Solidworks to be able to modify them for my purposes, so I drew one up myself.
I stole the ring size from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1764 because the ring I had already fit through that to attach it to a chain. I wish I could say I was also inspired by it, but unfortunately the person who commissioned me to design it had no knowledge of that thing (though I printed her one in the meantime).

You will need one of those little ringy things seen in the thumbnail, I stole that one off of an old free keychain I got somewhere. They shouldn't be too hard to find, or see merlinjim's comment below for instructions on how to make your own.
Then just print and attach to your favorite chain. (Makes a great gift too)
I like to print from an SD card when I'm printing things that I want to look nice, but I found that it wouldn't let me build from the card because the filename was too long. Just shorten the filename if you're having this problem too.

title: 1-1/2" wide x 2" tall hinge - No assembly required

description.text:
October 14, 2013
Per request, .step (2 versions) and .sat files have been added. I was NOT able to save this as a .step or .sat thru Solidwoks with the holes on the leaves included for some reason, I've no idea why. Anyway, here you go. Good luck, and have fun! Hello-
Here's a hinge I drew on request of an instructor at my little community college. It's all in one, and there is absolutely no assembly required! This hinge is 1.500" wide by 2.000" tall , the leaves are .075" thick, the outer diameter of the pin housing is .175" and each leaf has (2) .250" dia countersunk holes. The holes are located .500" from the centerline horizontally and .719" from the midpoint vertically.
Both leaves rotate 90 degrees from horizontal in one direction, and 45 degrees from horizontal the other direction. The pin diameter is 0.080" and has small bosses on each end to keep it in the part.
The pictures attached don't show the holes, as this was just as test print. Also, there's a short video in the "download this thing" area of this part.
I'm only publishing the .stl file right now, if you'd like me to send you the 2012 Solidworks .sldprt file, leave me a comment with your email address and I'll gladly send it to you. Let me know if you find this useful please!

The printer we are lucky enough to have at Kishwaukee College in Illinois is a Dimension uPrint SE Plus. We use the .stl manipulation and print management software that comes with the printer called CatalystEX, and we are currently running version 4.3 of that. This hinge was printed with a resolution of .010", solid infill, and with support material generation set to "smart". One hinge with thse parameters takes about 35 minutes to print in a flat position and about 90 minutes to print in a vertical orientation.

comments.text: I printed one of these and it wasn't functional, perhaps because I decreased the size slightly. I'll try again without altering the size, thanks for posting!

comments.text:
I'm sorry that it didn't work for you. I've never made any smaller than this original size, so maybe that's an issue. The way other printers use support material might have an impact on the functionality also. I use a pretty high-end (for 2012 at least, when they bought it) printer supplied by my school, and I printed this with the leaves of the hinge parallel to the printing platen and the pin holding circular feature facing up.
I hope you get a working version printed, let me know if I can help in any way.

custom design

After building my TOM I realized that it would be a good idea to ensure I always have by hex wrenches nearby in case things need adjusting.  I also thought it would be a good idea to have spare screws and nuts around in case I ever lose one when re-adjusting things.  I designed this box to clip onto the top or side of the TOM.  The box is big enough to hold all of the hex wrenches that came with my TOM kit and can also fit screws and nuts or other small parts if you so desire.
The photos I attached are of a slightly different version of this box.  The original version was exactly 10CM tall and was a bit too tall for my TOM to print.  The last two or three layers got all out of whack due to the nozzle running into the layer.  I have shrunk the box by 5mm so that should take care of the height problem.  Also, I had to do a fair bit of filing to get the lid to fit inside the box opening and to get the clip to slip onto the wooden frame of the TOM.  I have since altered the size of the lid and the clip so it should be easier in the future.  I have not tried printing the exact version I uploaded but it should work.  I have uploaded the openSCAD files so you can adjust the dimensions easily as you see fit.

You have to print the main body of the box upside down in order for the small clip to print properly.  Open the STL in Replicatorg and use the flip function to flip the box on the Z axis.  Then use the move function to make sure the box is sitting on the platform.
You may need to file or sand some parts down to get the lid to fit properly or to get the box to slip onto the side of the TOM properly.

I wanted to make sure the box closed tightly enough that the top wouldn't pop off easily when in transport.  If one were so inclined, you could scale down the main box portion and make two more; one for screws and one for nuts.

title: Ez3D Phoenix Print Bed Leveling Screw Mount

description.text: As delivered, the Ez3D Phoenix 3D printer does not provide any means for leveling the print bed. Replacing the original print bed mounts with this mount allows leveling screws to be added so print bed leveling can be accomplished.

The existing print bed mounts are removed and replaced with the modified mounts. The new mounts are all the same - no left and right parts. They are mounted upside down relative to the original mounts to allow space for leveling screws and springs.   
Use the PCB heat bed as a drilling guide for the leveling screw holes in the aluminum print bed.  
The new mounts are taped for M3 x .5 screws. It would also be possible to simply flip the original mounts over and drill them for the screws using the heat bed as a drilling guide.   
The heat bed and aluminum print bed are mounted using four M3 x .5 screws that are 30mm long. A spring is placed between the bottom of the heat bed and the top surface of the supports. Compression springs with a free length of  25 mm and a diameter in the area of 6 to 8 mm would be appropriate for this application.  
Set the bed height so the upper surface is in about the same relative location as when the print bed was mounted with the original Ez3D parts.  
The bed level is adjusted by turning the screws. The springs allow for easy movement while maintaining enough vertical force to keep the print bed stable.

This thing is a replacement for the stock combination of magnetic shield and base plate on the headset. There are a number of different versions available here.

V1 is just a flat plate, easy and fast to print. Picture 2 corresponds to V1 closed, picture 3 is V1 open. V2 comes closer to the original shape, but requires printing on top of a bed of support material, otherwise the surface looks bad. Again, open and closed designs are available The V2 closed IJMV2 is the special version I made for myself, it features my own logo embossed into a V2 closed piece, see pictures 1, 4 & 5. In order to install this, first take off the plush pads by simply pulling them off carefully (!). Undo the four screws that come to light. Next, using an exacto-knife or a small flat screwdriver, peel away the glued in piece of cloth. Don't worry, the glue is only around the perimeter and not neccessary to hold the piece back in place. Undo the four screws around the speaker grill, out with the old, in with the new and you're golden.
In case you chose the open design, you should be able to reuse the felt-like piece sticking underneath the original base to prevent dust from getting into your headset . I'd advise printing this in an opaque colour, but thats personal preference and material availability.

Rev 1.1: Changed the design and profile of the clasps. Everything fits a bit more snug now and doesn't stick out from the container nearly as far. The clasps even release enough to make removing the lid possible with out snapping something. The vapor treatment that I did on the white box made the clasp a little too flexable but everything still seems to function fine. The lid just closes a little too easy. The REV 1.0 files for the clasps will remain up in case that is the one you would prefer. REV 1.0:
I am trying to make a reliable latch system that I can use on any application. I have included the cut-out template with the sketchup file. This is just the first revision. I will continue to tweak this for a while and may design several different variations. This box as it is will work nicely as a geocache container if you use a small bead of silicone to make it water tight. Please take a picture if you make the box or latch. I would love to see how these print for others.

• Print Box with large opening towards the top. (20% infill, 2 Perimeters)
  • Print 2 Clasps and 2 Clips on their sides (20% infill, 2 Perimeters, brim may be helpful but not I did not use one)
  • Use an hobby knife to clean holes in box (bottom and top)
  • Remove excess print debris from clips and clasps making sure to retain shape of studs.
  • Insert clips and clasps in box as shown in the photos.
    (These should be a tight fit. The cut-outs are universal and the clips/clasps can be orient which ever way makes the most sense for you.)
    *Use acetone treatment on the box to really secure the latches or use superglue.

description.text: I recently got my new Thing-O-Matic and matching Mk1 Spindle( http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:3116 ). After a while of using it I found that the filament would become slack and slide off the the spindle with time. This lead to a lot of jams that were ruining prints. So I came up with the idea of using something to keep the filament on the spool base. Sitting down with OpenSCAD and a little experimentation I came up with these. The basic idea is that the pegs work as outside edges for the spindle and keep the filament from falling underneath. When I printed them I out I noticed two slight problems. The first being that there is not enough room inside the box to allow these on the outside of the spool. The second I noticed they seem to catch a little on the back side by the feed hole. The first problem was solved by cutting out notches in the bottom of the spool. The second ended up not really being a problem at all. While they catch a little it looks to be a slight thing and my extruder just pulls the filament over the peg with a click and it spins to the next peg. I have a stepstuder so I am not sure if this has more pull power than a DC motor powered but from watching the spindle it actually looks like less force needed to get over the pegs than required to pull it out from under the gap next to the spool and the box when it would fall off. Though if someone has problems with it I am sure that it can be adjusted in size to fit their needs. This is why the SCAD file is attached.

• Print out the set of 4 clips
  • Dismantle your MK1 spindle. You want to get to he bottom of the spool, I did this by removing the entire spool from the top. That was mainly because I have no screws on my top plate at the moment. It should be possible to just remove the bottom plate and access it that way.
  • Use the clips to determine where you need to notch your spool. I did mine roughly in 4ths but you may want to experiment.
  • Cut out a notch about 5mm deep and the width of your clips so that when the clips are on they are flush with the outside of the spool.
  • Reassemble the spindle and enjoy a time free of jams.

title: Durable quick release bike light mount with Gopro (or similar) adapter

description.text:
edit
You can totally fit normal size phone there.... and go hunt some pokemons!!!
/edit... Bike light mount that doubles as a GoPro mount for a 22mm diameter handle bar! Story I've meant to do this for a really long time (took me 100orso broken rubberbands to piss me off enough to finally design this :) Simply put this is durable bike light mount with quick release for a bike handle bar of about 22mm diameter. The quick release itself is a bootstrap from a small miniski but any similar (with strap width < 20mm) can be used. I have also added a "security / pull down helper (Anti-theft block)" at the end of the strap. This is to help pull it tighter with gloves on and stopping some clown stealing your strap so easily. To go bit further, I've included alternative design of the pull down helper that has magnet holes added for a 5mm cube magnets. This is for securing it to a metal surface during the ride and not making it fly around and banging on stuff while you ride. (This is optional..I don't know how much of a problem this is going to be but these worked like a charm) Also added a gopro mount adapter for those action packed runs to the store.. or something :) and when done / dark, just swap the light back on. Design goals were: To make it work as intended! (#1 most of the time :) To make it durable (small bangs wouldn't damage it in the bike shed). To make it combatible with different sized torches. To design it so that there are no extra appendices required on torches (sharp corners could eat thru pockets). To design it to have simple quick release mechanism. To design it to be small as possible. To have it secured in place near permanently and not slipping around while driving -> nuts&bolts ftw. If possible, make it compatible with gopro.

Stuff you'll need:

  • Nuts and bolts:
    3x12 2pcs -OPTIONAL-
    3x40 2pcs
    3x30 4pcs
    3mm nyloc nut 8pcs
    5mm nut for GoPro mount -OPTIONAL-

  • Self locking strap with 20mm strap or velcro

  • 5mm cube magnets (1or2) -OPTIONAL-
    • Instructions: Print (duh ;) Clean if needed. Lay down the strap on the groove. Insert the 3x40 screws thru perpendicular holes to the strap as pictured (you may need to turn those in all the way since the clearence is designed to be smaller than the thickness of the strap) Cut the strap to the desired length and melt the end fibers with heat source of your choosing. Optional Insert 1/2x 5mm cube magnets to their slots with glue. Cut holes to the strap acc to the holes in the pull down helper block (lay the block over the strap and punch thru). Sandwich the strap between the blocks. Insert 2x 3x12 bolts and thighten. /Optional Mount it to a desired place on handle bar. Insert 4x 3x30 bolts and tighten. Ride like the wind!

description.text:
An adapter for the cheap eBay 40 watt laser cutters to let you attach the hose directly to the back of the cutter. This allows you to use an in line blower fan, which eliminates positive air pressure in the hose and lowers the chance of fumes leaking into the room.

  • http://www.amazon.com/dp/B003BMATFK/
  • http://www.amazon.com/dp/B00LLYYPVY/

• Print 2 pieces. (I had the most luck printing them standing upright.)

title: SMA antenna sleeve. For protection and grip.

description.text:
This is a simple sleeve that goes over the SMA connector of the antenna and covers the area where the SMA and antenna wire meet. This is generally the weakest part and gets bent in a crash so it moves the stress point up further. There is a slight bevel on the top edge so it's not as sharp.  
It's also great to use for grip when screwing the antenna in and out and I use it on all my antennas.  
It can be a tight fit so adjust filament flow rate up or down to suit tightness.
It can be a tight fit so adjust filament flow rate up or down to suit tightness. One end is slightly beveled to present a less sharp edge to the wire in case of a bad crash.

A jig for winding coils from magnet wire. Made for a project that required a 1mm thick coil made with 40 gauge wire with 900 turns. The coil was held together by adding small drops of superglue while winding, and kapton tape keeps it from sticking to the jig. The screws are all held on the 3d printed parts using the heat-set threaded inserts from McMaster-Carr (4-40 screws) http://www.mcmaster.com/#catalog/121/3303/=w1cxzg The standoff spacers and the handle are 8-32 Nylon threaded hex standoffs that are 1.5" long with matching nylon screws and nuts for the ends. Update: we found that using sewing machine bobbins was effective for winding the coils, and using red fingernail polish works better for gluing the coils because it can be dissolved with acetone. Added a photo showing the bobbin in the jig.

I decided to use XT60 connectors on power supply lead on my 3d printer. I designed a cover for female connector and male connector panel mount.   
I mistakenly named files. XT60_Male is actually female connector cover, while XT60_Female1 and 2 are for male connector mount.   
Assembly is pretty simple. For Female connector just solder wires and click the cover. For Male - solder wires, click the connector to inner part, mount both parts to your panel and screw them with M3 screws. Please note, that once you assemble connectors you can't disassemble it without breaking printed parts. At least I could not :)  
It appears that my printed parts (on the photos) do not fully cover holes in the panel. Moreover screws do not allow female connector to be fully inserted into male one. I fixed models so that they have a little larger circle hole covers and a little farther screw holes. I fixed this in STL files, but have not had a chance to re-print models yet.   
I am also including Solidworks projects so that you can adjust models if needed.  
UPD: I re-printed covers and added new photos of the result. Photos match models now

description.text:
I am sorry.  Really really sorry if you wake up with one of these as a surprise.  I should have never done this.  
I am having some trouble getting used to CPAP therapy, and this remix is part of me getting used to the idea of having something on my face when I sleep.  It's a rendition of how I feel right now.  
It's way too big to print on any normal desktop printer.  I suppose if the body was scaled down a bit and the legs were printed separately, this could be made printable.

I used Autodesk MeshMixer to do a straight combine of the two STL's.  
It's too big to print without making it in sections.  If you wanted to be really mean, perhaps the legs and tail parts should be made with a flexible material.

comments.text:
Ha Ha this is brilliant! I will print one off at some point and clip to my CPAP.
On the subject of CPAP has anyone ever come across a makeshift CPAP device that could be used overnight back packing rather that lugging the big heavy unit and 12v battery? I'm thinking a powerful DC inline fan to connect to the CPAP pipe, possible variable speed / pressure adjuster. I know its not ideal but I'm figuring its better than nothing.
comments.author: prep2

comments.text: I too have been considering something along that line. This is a beginning part to consider that I found: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1695246 However, you still have to consider the CFM on the motor stacked against its power draw (in amps). Note that amps = battery volume = WEIGHT when camping!!!

comments.text: I have used a CPAP machine for over 13 years.  I use the full face mask version.  When I first got it it made such a HUGE difference with my life, I finally had energy each day. Amazing difference for me.  Anyway, my wife is scared to death of the face hugger and spiders. This would scare the crap out of her I want to print it! My print volume is a touch over 250 millimeters cubed.  I'm thinking to chop off the tail and put a cpap hose clamp so it looks like the hose is the tail and then hollow out the bottom so it would fit over top of my existing mask clipping somewhere, then leaving it on until my wife notices.  Lol.   Thanks for the idea!

author: Bartimaeus

title: Freehand Foot for Pfaff Sewing Machine

description.text: I designed this presser foot for freehand sewing (with the feed dog disengaged).  The circular profile allows the material to feed smoothly from all sides.  The key to using it is to remove almost all the pressure on the presser foot - I do this using rubber bands.

Printed in PLA with 0.2mm layers (finer may be better).  You'll want to lightly sand the underside of the foot so the fabric glides smoothly.  You'll also need a 1/16" dia, 5/8" long steel pin.  
To lighten the pressure of the foot, I use four #33 rubber bands - two sets of two in parallel and then loop the two pairs together to increase the length.  I then just hooked the open ends together with a paperclip.  Loop the rubber bands around the business end of the sewing machine and underneath the edge of the foot mechanism as shown.  You can increase or decrease the tension on the foot by shifting where the rubber bands contact the body of the machine. You want equal tension on the front and back and just enough tension overall so that the foot just barely presses against the fabric.

comments.text:
Looks good! But when it comes to free motion sewing, I'm just not there yet - too scared :)
But I wanted to tell you about this: I don't know if your Pfaff has this, but mine has a "hidden" (but explained in the manual) second presser foot position that just touches the fabric (depends on the fabric thickness, of course). It can be found by moving presser foot lever sideways a bit while you lower it. It somehow gets caught before it goes all the way down. If you machine has it as well, you could try it instead of the rubber bands ...
comments.author: maritacovarrubias

comments.text: Thanks for the tip!  Mine is a pretty low-end machine, but I'll check it out.  Getting rid of the rubber bands would be nice...
comments.author: maritacovarrubias

comments.text: Could you achieve the proper pressure by adjusting the location of the pin to change the foot height?
comments.author: paradug

comments.text: It would probably be difficult to adjust the pressure this way because the downward force is pretty constant over a large range of travel.

title: ODROID X2 to MLAB breakout frame

description.text: 3D Printable Breakout frame which mechanically converts the ODROID-X2 to MLAB (http://wiki.mlab.cz/) electronic prototyping and development system. The design even provides great increase of mechanical durability of weak ODROID's PCB board. The breakout frame uses standard M3x12mm screws and nuts which are used normally in MLAB system.

The breakout frame is designed to be easily printable on almost all 3D FDM printers, it can be printed from ABS or PLA plastic with good results. But an inspection of trace placement in thin walls is required after slicing. The breakout frame model has bottom holes for nuts covered by one layer of material. This technological material allows slicing software to plan a bridge over all holes. The bridge layer must be drilled of after printing by a 3mm drill. Hexagonal nuts should be inserted from bottom side to the prepared holes. M3x12mm screws for mount mounting ODROID board should be screwed from the top side. Use of the breakout frame is illustrated by pictures of the radio meteor detection station. http://wiki.mlab.cz/doku.php?id=en:rmds Other file formats and up to date sources are freely available from MLAB's SVN Repository.

title: Skateboard hole drilling jig or 80/20 aluminum bracket

description.text: This can be used to recreate the skateboard hole jig as described or you can use it for any other kind of hole jig that uses 80/20 style t-slot aluminum.  We wanted the holes to stay perfectly parallel, but we wanted to be able to spread the holes pattern apart for different sized skate boards.  I will add another picture once they all print and are being used on our longboards.

You will need 40-50 inches of 1 inch t-slot aluminum. In 80/20 brand that is called 10-10
2 pieces of 3 inch by 6 inch aluminum marked and drilled using the hole jig template print. The holes are small on the template, but should fit a mechanical pencil. I did not use this jig, but marked everything with a height gauge. I haven't even printed the jig, but it seemed like a good way for others to mark their plates without having to measure. I could upload a dxf with the hole locations if needed. I cut the aluminum on the table saw and drilled the holes in a drill press to keep them straight. Also I drilled one hole at a time, then bolted the aluminum together as I went to keep them aligned.
8 10-32 bolts and nuts. The ones in the photo were 1 inch, but I replaced them with 1/2 inch after I found them to be too long
8 t-slot nuts and bolts (you can print t slot nuts from thingiverse, but I had some) The nuts have to be the right size width, but when you have the right ones, they pop in really well.
4 prints of the jig. These were printed on an Ultimaker 2, so all tolerances were based on our own known variables.

comments.text: Ok, I just added two more files.  I made a cap for the ends of the t slot aluminum and I made a drill bit holder to attach to the aluminum so that I don't have to go find the correct drill bit for the skateboards.  I haven't yet printed them and tested the tolerances,  but I will in the next day or so, when the machine isn't printing other things.

This is a Matlab script to convert a surface (technically a function of two variables) into a solid that can be printed. I wanted a way to visualize (in solid 3D) mathematical functions, and this gives you a way of converting from a mathematical description, directly to a solid. I haven't uploaded the scripts here, because they are already at http://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/30709-surf2solidMatlab file central and keeping them up to date at one point seemed more sensible.

The idea here is to create a surface in Matlab, and then be able to print it. There is a STL writer for Matlab (see below), but a surface isn't a closed solid, so all I've really done here is write a script that adds walls and a bottom so that the object is printable. The scripts allow you to change a few parameters like the minimum height of the walls and the scale of the object. There are two scripts, one for converting a function of cartesian co-ordinates, and the other for polar cylindrical co-ordinates. Pick the one you like, and have a look at the example scripts to see how to call them, or the comments in the code. But if you want to print the output, you also need Bill McDonald's surf2stl.m function, which can also be obtained from http://www.mathworks.com/matlabcentral/fileexchange/4512-surf2stl on Matlab central. Matlab isn't free, but if you don't have access you might try Octave, which is an almost compatible free set of software, though I haven't tested it works there.

remixed_from.title: QU-BD One Up / Two Up Nut retainer and Fan Mount

description.text:
I preferred this orientation, so added some angles so the zip ties could hold it at the proper angle. Also tweaked the nozzle end to try and direct the air flow more across the print. Hope it works well, the original was a nice design, I just started about 3 weeks ago with this stuff and haven't dialed it in so thing fit perfectly yet, this is my way of adjusting. REDONE: 3/07/15
Ok, so I added a duct to redirect the upper air flow towards peek tube, lowered it and changed the angle slightly to direct the main flow towards the print better, also, and this was the main thing, set the portion that touches the stepper offset to line it up in the middle of the nozzle. I posted both directions depending on what side of the stepper your filament goes on. Unintended feature of this new version, I can now use the large zip-ties to attach it, if needed.
I did 0.2 layer height, and 25% infill.

comments.text: Ok gang, Have upgraded my X Gantry and am using DDeGonge888's extruder for the Anubis.  The fan duct that I remixed sit's offset a bit and could be lower.  I'm currently printing a new offset version in order to center the ducts on the nozzle and lower it a bit.  If it works, I'll post the new files, will have a centered, left offset, and right offset version depending on how you mount your extruder.
comments.author: Joe_Snuffy

comments.text: The original is one of the first upgrades I tried to print because I knew heat creep on the PEEK tube is a problem but just before it was getting ready to bridge the upper duct the Y axis belt (Still original bearing holder) slipped and shifted everything off several mm and ruined the print so I stopped it. (And printed the Y axis upgrade part)  A few days later I noticed that if I just trimmed it off at the first duct and hung it straight down it would divert air right on the PEEK tube so I added a second always on fan (Eventually I added a switch for it when I printed the controller box) and temporarily mounted it similar to how you did but hanging straight down. I have the upgrade extruder assembly (highly recommended) with a fan mount and duct on it (similar to this one but mounts to the new extruder body) with the normal fan. Spending 3 bucks and getting the ceramic insulation for QU-BD is also recommended, now my PEEK temperatures stay below 40C (As measured by an IR no contact thermometer) almost all the time even printing at 225-230C. I printed another duct and mount but this time stopped the print intentionally and will find a way to more permanently mount it when I add the upgrade gantry and end switch mounts hopefully this week
comments.author: longjohn119

comments.text: Looks neat, thanks for the remix, and I hope it works well for you too! Looks a good solid print.

comments.text: Thanks for the input.  Working well so far, haven't had the issues you're speaking of yet.  Still working on getting print speeds up, this I think was at 50mm/s (my first successful prints were at a only 10mm/s).  Have cranked up the amps on the stepper, more concerned at keeping it cool atm.  I may tweak the part that rests on the stepper to change the angle of the whole thing a bit if I run into issues.  Great piece you made there, I hope to one day be that good at designing things, still learning that program as well.
comments.author: QUBD_Broadlands

comments.text: Your stepper motor(s) shouldn't run any higher than just lukewarm to touch, if the filament is jamming overdriving the stepper won't help and will only cause you more problems because it chews up the filament so badly it won't move even if the jam clears

There comes a time in every herb enthusiast's life when materials and circumstances are less than ideal for making a proper joint. This is when the time honored tradition of using an emptied cigarette comes into play. This kit will help you stuff the new contents into the emptied cigarette and tamp it down as you go. A little research shows you should remove the filter to reduce the effect on potency.  
No longer a work in progress as the ramrod is now setup to print horizontally with a triangular shaft.

remixed_from.author: Ahasuerus
remixed_from.title: Circular fan duct for Prusa Mendel

description.text:
A PLA cooling fan duct for a Bukobot with a Bukoschnozzle hot end and initial X-carriage version (with plastic printed linear bearing holders rather than the new all metal design).  It should work with either a Vanilla/Green or Duo and with either version of the Bukoschnozzle wooden hot-end insulator design.  
One of my design goals for this fan was that it had to be unobtrusive and so it mounts up underneath the X carriage between the two steel rods. This does mean that the top of the fan intake is partially obstructed by the rear linear bearing but that seemed a small price to pay.

description.header: Things I changed from the original design by Ahasuerus:
description.text:
• increase size so that it fits 50mm fan instead of 40mm
  • increase size of the center space to allow for the larger Bukoschnozzle heater block (ID now 33mm)
  • cut out an area on the topside to allow the duct to clear the x-carriage linear bearing holders
  • slightly increase relative aperture of fan outlet by ~20% (to increase air flow)
  • rake inwards the outside annulus edge to increase visibility of printed parts underneath
  • add a mounting arm to allow fan duct to be attached to the x-carriage using a cable tie
  • removed indentation on one side of air funnel from original model
    • I have uploaded a second (larger) version of the fan duct which has a internal diameter which is 4mm larger (37mm). This gives more clearance between the hot end and the duct or allows you to position the nozzle closer to the center.

• Bukobot with Bukoschnozzle hot end and older x-carriage design
  • Good insulation around hot end. I didn't allow very much clearance between the hot end and fan duct so either you need good insulation so that the duct doesn't melt or print it in ABS (you want good insulation anyway due to the increase airflow around the nozzle). Some ideas here: http://bukobot.com/hot-end-thermal-management You can also use the larger version if your insulation isn't as good.
  • A 50x50x10mm 12V fan with around 10-11 CFM airflow
  • Some cable ties.
  • Two M3 screws which are 16-20mm in length and two M3 nuts (although cable ties could also potentially be used to attach the fan to the duct)

• Print it.
  • Install it. If you are worried about vibration against the x-carriage then you could use a small ball of Blutac on top of the unattached top corner although I haven't seen any problems here - the cable tie holds it quite securely. If the fan duct hole doesn't line up with your hot end you may need to loosen your hot-end mounting bolts and move the hot end further back.
  • Wire it up. See here for some pointers: http://bukobot.com/pla-print-cooling-fan to allow the firmware to control the fan speed.
  • Enable cooling in your slicer profiles. You don't want to run the fan at 100% all the time as this can cause extra stringing. For the majority of printing it should either be off or run at a low speed - most slicers support this.

title: Parametric Model Rocket Fin Alignment Tool

description.text:
If you build model rockets you will probably know that aligning the fins on your rocket can be a fiddly task.  From measuring up the tube, to mounting the fins at right angles to the body, mistakes can lead to a rocket that does not fly quite true.  
I looked at the commercially available jig from Estes as well as some other DIY solutions.  However I wanted something simple to use that was reasonably scalable.  
This is what I came up with....  
The tools is a jig that inserts over the body tube of the rocket.  It is parametric so you can change the number of fins, tube size, fin width etc. to suit.  
The tool holds your fins perfectly true whilst glue sets on the model rocket.

Measure your rocket parts in particular:
  • The outer diameter of your body tube
  • The width of your fins
  • The number of fins
    • Add the measured dimensions to the openscad model and adjust the jig height, wall width and the gap width (for the root of the fin to prevent glue bonding the jig to the model). Print the part, clean up any flash and insert over the end of your rocket tube. Insert your fins with the root edge glued. Wait!

comments.text: Very nicely done. Probably the most complete, adaptable, and stable take on a 3D printed fin jig I've seen.

comments.text: If only we had 3d-printers when making model rockets back in the days. I sanded those balsa fins for hours to make them teardrop shaped in the direction of the oncoming air. We were going for maximum height and speed so every detail counted. From the sound the rocket made when coming nose first on it's way down I think they were off symmetry by a little bit. Sounded like it was spinning. We had no parachute and no clip on the motor and a plugged motor holding tube meant it was shot out from the rocket as soon as the parachute charge went off. Ejecting that mass for that final extra little boost. Took quite a long time for it to come down so it must have gone up pretty high. Vanished on the second launch.
comments.author: Norwegian1

comments.text: love those type of memories!   We had about 5 clear acres surrounded by trees... We would launch them untill they disapeared into the trees.  Come  fall when the leaves fell, we'd usually find a few rockets in the branches too!  usually recycled the cones, parachutes and fins (if the paint held up) and spend the winter building new rockets.  Rinse... Repeat... lol...

author: Justblair

description.text:
i hacked together an ABS fume hood for my printer.  i have a roll of plastic that only extrudes at 250Âº so i had to do something.
if i stick my face between the fan and the cupcake it STINKS of abs fumes. there is no smell whatsoever in the exhaust.  if i run the printer for a while without the fan on the entire room stinks, after turning the fan on it cleared the whole room in about 15 min.  I have been using it for a few days now, not sure how long the carbon in the filter will last.

you will need.
lots of hot glue
a bunch of cardboard
a good adjustable speed computer fan
a charcoal cabin air filter for a car. i used a VW jetta carbon cabin air filter
sharp knife
optional paint build the enclosure and hot glue the crap out of all of the seams. hot glue the filter into the frame/hood you made making sure there are no holes or gaps. hot glue the fan into the hood. i hot glued the whole thing to the shelf above my cupcake. i used this fan,
http://tinyurl.com/64bjpud (amazon link to a silverstone 120mm fan) it pushes an insane amount of air, is very quiet (about the same as the power supply) and is adjustable. it can pull enough air at the lowest setting to more than keep up with the fumes and its nearly silent at that speed. i painted it with the remnants of a can of black spray-paint i had

comments.text: its the new smooth shiny 3dink plastic.  its really nice compared to the old stuff, and prints incredibly well but needs to be at 250, all other plastic i feed the machine melts at 220 no problem so its not therm. settings.

This is a makeover of the "A-Mazing Box" by wizard23 (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1481). This version is done in pure geometry on OpenSCAD and requires no images, perl scripts, or bump maps. Maze channels are cylindrical, so the action is very precise and smooth. The box's inner and outer surfaces are smooth. The downside is a very long compilation time in OpenSCAD. The STL files are posted for people who only want to print and have fun with the maze box. Update Feb. 24, 2015: Created new version that defines the much more difficult inverted box, with the maze printed on the inside of the lid. Pulled the maze definition out into its own include file that can be used for either puzzle. Also uploaded a new, harder maze! Update December 17, 2015: Noting that the last one I printed is way too tight, I rewrote the openSCAD to expand the lid and outer shell outward by one tolerance. New STL files for maze_box1.stl and maze_box2.stl should fit better.

The OpenSCAD is fully parameterized for all important dimensions such as the box height, radius, size and depth of channels, etc. The maze itself is just a list of line segments, making it very easy for anyone to design their own custom maze. The maze definition is put in its own file, and then a wrapper file is needed to include both the maze definition file and one of the maze box libraries, maze_box_lib.scad or maze_box_inv_lib.scad (depending on whether you wan the maze visible to the solver or not). Use the inclued files "maze_box1.scad" and "maze_box1_inv.scad" as example wrappers. Compile, render, and export from the top-level wrapper file. Note that cylindrical objects like the maze box almost always print better (higher quality) if each cylinder is printed separately, so there is no motion of the extruder path to and from the cylinder exterior. Most slicers should be able to separate the two volumes in the print, so that you can print them separately, if you prefer. Also, if printing with translucent filament, avoid infill or "gap fill" in the walls, but adjust perimeter overlap or extrusion width as necessary to get the cylinders to print walls with three or four perimeters only, which increases the translucence and brings out the color. The maze definition file in this Thing (and the accompanying STL file) is called "maze1def.scad" and matches the maze in the original A-Mazing Box. To show how easy it is to make a new definition and create an alternative maze box, I have also included a new and harder maze called "maze2def.scad". I hope that I have made the format straightforward enough that it will spawn many remixes, in which people post their own maze definition files. I will also give a nod to http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:595481 which I did not know about at the time I wrote the code for this one, but which uses similar OpenSCAD methods to get more or less the same end result, although they have a clever maze definition method using ASCII art.

comments.text: I draw the maze out on a piece of graph paper, then label all of the channels with numbers horizontally and vertically.  The maximum values in X and Y need to be entered in the file as "xgrid" and "ygrid".  Then everything else needs to be inside a block "module make_maze(i) {...}".  The "i" here is used because the maze is mapped 3 times onto a cylinder, so this routine will be called to map the maze three times, at 120 degrees apart.
